p: Cardiotropic viruses directly attack cardiac cells at the initial phase, followed by a secondary inflammatory response that can lead to further cardiac damage. It is likely that coronavirus is following a similar pathway. Indeed, the ACE2 receptor plays a role in the direct cardiac damage, as well as vascular involvement in COVID-19 infection. In autopsies from the SARS outbreak in 2002, 35% of heart samples revealed the presence of viral RNA in the myocardium, and it was associated with reduced ACE2 expression. It is believed SARS-CoV-2 may share the same mechanism, with direct cardiac muscle damage playing a role in both the myocarditis and HF in COVID-19-infected individuals. Cardiac muscle involvement has been evident by increased cardiac biomarkers in a sizable portion of patients [ 42]. Additionally, autopsy studies of COVID-19 have demonstrated the presence of mononuclear infiltrate in the myocardium, with related cardiomyocyte necrosis [ 43]. Finally, acute lung injury and ARDS result in right heart strain, with right ventricular (RV) dilation and dysfunction, and high positive end expiratory pressure (PEEP) use while on ventilation can also worsen cardiac function [ 44].
